title: How Netflix Rebuilt Its Tech Stack for 100M+ Users
summary: Netflix migrated from a monolithic architecture to hundreds of microservices over seven years, enabling it to scale to 100+ million subscribers while achieving 99.99% availability.
background: In 2008, Netflix suffered a major database corruption. This crisis prompted a complete architectural rethink — moving from a monolith to AWS-hosted microservices.
response: Netflix built a Chaos Engineering practice (Chaos Monkey), invested in circuit breakers (Hystrix), and adopted a decentralised team model where each team owned its services end-to-end.
outcome: Netflix now operates hundreds of microservices, deploys thousands of times per day, and handles 500,000+ streaming requests per second during peak.
lessons: Design for failure from the start
Microservices enable independent scaling and deployment
Chaos engineering builds resilience through deliberate failure
discussion_questions: What were the key trade-offs in moving from monolith to microservices?
How does Chaos Engineering change the culture of an engineering team?
